content: The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act is amended to include new procedures for the collection and delivery of marked absentee ballots of absent overseas uniformed services voters. The Presidential designee establishes procedures for collecting and delivering marked absentee ballots of absent overseas uniformed services voters in federal elections. The designee ensures that ballots collected before the deadline are delivered to the appropriate election officials in states before the polls close on election day. The Presidential designee contracts with express mail providers to collect and deliver marked absentee ballots of absent overseas uniformed services voters before the polls close on election day. The Presidential designee contracts with the United States Postal Service for the delivery of absentee ballots before the deadline at noon on the last Tuesday before the election, with the option to establish alternative deadlines for certain locations. The Presidential designee may establish alternative deadlines for certain locations to ensure timely delivery of absentee ballots. States are prohibited from refusing marked absentee ballots not delivered by the postal service. A tracking mechanism is implemented for the delivery of marked absentee ballots. The entity responsible for delivering marked absentee ballots for a general election must provide a way for voters to confirm delivery to election officials. An overseas uniformed services voter is defined as described in section 107(5)(A). Appropriations are authorized for the Presidential designee to carry out this section. The Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act applies to general elections for Federal office after November 1, 2010. Conforming amendments include federal responsibilities for collecting and delivering marked absentee ballots for overseas uniformed services voters. State responsibilities are also outlined in the Act. State responsibilities under the Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act are amended to include processing and accepting marked absentee ballots of absent overseas uniformed services voters. The Presidential designee is required to inform anticipated absent overseas uniformed services voters of voting procedures for the November 2008 general election. The Presidential designee must report on the utilization of procedures for collecting and delivering marked absentee ballots after each general election for Federal office held after January 1, 2008. The report should include a description of the utilization of procedures during the general election, such as the number of marked absentee ballots collected and delivered. Additionally, a report on the status of the implementation of the program for the collection and delivery of marked absentee ballots must be submitted to the congressional defense committees within one year of the enactment of the Act. The report under section 103A of the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act must include a status of the program implementation and detailed steps taken for November 2009 and November 2010. Definitions include terms like "absent overseas uniformed services voter" and "Presidential designee." The term "congressional defense committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives.
